description: Borrowed from French grade (‚Äúa grade, degree‚Äù), from Latin gradus (‚Äúa step, pace, degree‚Äù), from Proto-Italic *gra√∞us, from Proto-Indo-European *g ∞rad ∞-, *g ∞red ∞- (‚Äúto walk, go‚Äù).
Cognate with Gothic êå≤êçÇêåπêå∏êçÉ (gri√æs, ‚Äústep, grade‚Äù), Bavarian Gritt (‚Äústep, stride‚Äù), Lithuanian gr√¨diju (‚Äúto go, wander‚Äù).

entries.meaning: A rating.
examples: This fine-grade coin from 1837 is worth a good amount.
I gave him a good grade for effort.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Canada, US) Performance on a test or other evaluation(s), expressed by a number, letter, or other symbol; a score.
examples: He got a good grade on the test.
You need a grade of at least 80% in first-year calculus to be admitted to the CS major program.

entries.meaning: A degree or level of something; a position within a scale; a degree of quality.
(linguistics) Degree (any of the three stages (positive, comparative, superlative) in the comparison of an adjective or an adverb).
A slope (up or down) of a roadway or other passage
examples: The grade of this hill is more than 5 percent.

entries.meaning: (Canada, US, education) A level of primary and secondary education.
examples: Clancy is entering the fifth grade this year.
Clancy starts grade five this year.

entries.meaning: (Canada, education) A student of a particular grade (used with the grade level).
examples: The grade fives are on a field trip.

entries.meaning: An area that has been flattened by a grader (construction machine).
The level of the ground.
examples: This material absorbs moisture and is probably not a good choice for use below grade.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) A gradian.
(geometry) In a linear system of divisors on an n-dimensional variety, the number of free intersection points of n generic divisors.
A harsh scraping or cutting; a grating.
(systematics) A taxon united by a level of morphological or physiological complexity that is not a clade.
(medicine) The degree of malignity of a tumor expressed on a scale.
(ophthalmology, Philippines) An eyeglass prescription.

verbs.description: grade (third-person singular simple present grades, present participle grading, simple past and past participle graded)

entries.meaning: (chiefly Canada, US) To assign scores to the components of an academic test, or to overall academic performance.
To organize in grades.
To flatten, level, or smooth a large surface, especially with a grader.
examples: to grade land before building on it

entries.meaning: (sewing) To remove or trim part of a seam allowance from a finished seam so as to reduce bulk and make the finished piece more even when turned right side out.
To apply classifying labels to data (typically by a manual rather than automatic process).
examples: Brain scans were graded on a five-point scale of atrophy.

entries.meaning: (linguistics) To describe, modify or inflect so as to classify as to degree.
(intransitive) To pass imperceptibly from one grade into another.
examples: And there were circles even beyond these ‚Äì [‚Ä¶] humanity grading and drifting beyond the educated vision, until no earthly invitation can embrace it.

entries.meaning: (Canada, no longer current, intransitive) To pass from one school grade into the next.
examples: I graded out of grade two and three and arrived in Miss Hanson's room.
